string.text: You are affected by PTSD from watching your closest friend and former travelling companion get torn to shreds by a Whirligig Anomaly.
You have grown fond of cooking and eating mutant meat during your time in the Zone, and know plenty of recipes for preparing mutants.

You have crippling gambling debt. In addition to your military duties you're always on the lookout for extracurricular money-making activities as you're desperate to make enough money here to pay off your debts.
You are obsessed with pushing further north, and want to one day explore the Chernobyl Reactor.
You have recently turned to Christianity and Jesus after having done and experienced horrible things in the Zone.
You are long divorced. You hope your deployment to the Zone will help you forget about your ex-wife, who left you years ago but whom you still can't get over.
You regret coming to the Zone and long to escape back out to the normal world.

You found an old worn copy of 'The Way of Zen' by Alan Watts. In a desperate attempt to cope with the stress of the Zone you have turned to it, hoping Zen Buddhism might give you some sort of peace. You don't have any deeper understanding but you tell yourself muttering random quotes from the book helps somehow.
You are a habitual gambling addict. You try to engage people you meet in the Zone in casual wagers whenever the opportunity arises.
Before coming to the Zone your girlfriend aborted your baby. You wanted to keep it and start a family, and the conflict ruined your relationship.
You kept your habit from the outside world of writing figures in a small black leatherbound accounts book: artifacts sold, bullets spent, cigarettes borrowed, people killed.
You used to be a graveyard night guard before joining the army.
You used to be a village electrician before joining the army.
Before joining the army you used to be a night taxi driver who knew every pothole. Here in the Zone you map anomalies by the same memory trick.
You used to sell seeds at a market in Kiev. You still use seed envelopes to sort and store spare bullets.
You were a locksmith before joining the army. You still pick random padlocks and doors you come across to keep up the skill.
You used to be a night baker before joining the army. You employ your old knowledge to bake flatbreads on engine blocks and over campfires.
You keep a cracked snowglobe of your Ukraine hometown in an inside pocket. You take it out and shake it whenever the homesickness becomes too great.
You came to the Zone promising your mother it was your final deployment before leaving the army and getting a normal job. She died alone from pneumonia while you where in here.
You came to the Zone after your wife took the kids and left saying "choose either us or the bottle".
You have a daughter on the outside who sometimes sends you postcards and letters. It's the only thing that still keeps you going.
You keep a single domino piece on you - the double six. You flip it whenever a decision feels too big.

You carry a cracked and broken Zippo lighter engraved with a monogram - your only memento of your childhood sweetheart who died in a car accident. You still reach for it out of habit whenever you light a cigarette, despite years having passed since it broke.
You used to be a concrete tester before joining the army. You have a habit of tapping walls to see if they are solidly constructed in case you need to take shelter from an emission.
You used to be the night cashier at a 24h store before joining the army. Your sleep schedule hasn't reset even after all these years and you have trouble sleeping at night.
You have taken up origami in an attempt to stay sane in the Zone. You like folding empty cigarette packs into paper cranes and leaving them in unexpected places.
You were a grave digger before joining the army.

After your deployment to the Zone was announced you attempted to propose to your girlfriend. She laughed at you in response, saying she needs stability and not a man who smells like gunpowder and PTSD.
You have a sister in Canada who sends you money to help you in your life in the Zone. You constantly struggle with the pressure of not letting her down.

You were brought up by your mother to keep meticulous track of your income and expenses after your father got jailed for twenty years over fraud and tax evasion charges when you were eight years old. You still keep receipts of everything you buy and sell, despite there being no taxes or authority in the Zone.
You used to be a cinema projectionist before joining the army. You have a vast knowledge of movies and film trivia and enjoy talking about it - particularly the classics.
You were a complete failure before joining the army, a college dropout who couldn't hold on to a job. The military has given you new purpose and structure.

You keep a folded and worn photo of your ex-girlfriend's dog in an inside pocket. The ex-girlfriend was a cold-hearted bitch you're glad to see the back of, but her dog was the most endearing creature you've ever come across.
You were deployed to the Zone along with your two good army buddies in the same platoon. You've had to bury both at this point, and their ghosts still haunt you.
You used to be a slaughterhouse worker before joining the army. Blood and smell don't bother you and hunting and butchering mutants comes naturally to you.
You have developed a slight limp in your right leg after a close encounter with a pseudodog. You're still not used to the constant dull pain.

Your ex-wife left with your daughter, who you haven't seen since she was eight. You send half your earnings to her in envelopes, hoping she follows your instructions in the enclosed letters to put the money away for an education and make better life decisions than you.

You've been in the Zone for several years. You can't remember the last time someone adressed you by your full given name, and your memories of the normal world are becoming hazy. You sometimes worry that you're losing touch with your old self and will never be able to go back to the normal world.
You are addicted to betting on fights in the arena in Rostok.
You are scared of being out at night in the Zone after a close encounter with a Poltergeist almost cost you your life.
You grew up dirt poor and couldn't afford a higher education, so joining the army seemed like your best bet for a future. You never thought you'd be deployed to somewhere like the Zone.

The Zone was your first deployment on active combat duty. You have spent years here now, but still can't get used to the violence and death. Firefights stress you out and taking lives never gets easier, even when it's done in self-defence. Sometimes you see the faces of the people you've killed in your nightmares.

You are addicted to morphine. It started as a medical necessity after sustaining a minor combat injury in the Zone, but it quickly became your only comfort to deal with the mental stress of life in the Zone.

When you were still fairly fresh in the Zone you were part of a squad sent on a dangerous mission into the Red Forest. You were left gravely injured after stepping into an anomaly and would have died were it not for a random Duty patrol passing by. Since then you've been extremely wary of pushing northward, and you're extremely uncomfortable whenever you're north of Rostok.
You give your firearms female names, and you sometimes talk to them out loud.
You keep a journal where you record written summaries of your adventures in the Zone. Sometimes you subconsciously mutter whatever you're currently writing down out loud.

You had a best friend growing up who was incredibly charismatic, industrious and brave. He always said the two of you would go on adventures exploring the world together as soon as you turned 18. He died of a brain hemorrhage three days before his 18th birthday. You signed up for the army soon after, thinking a tour in the Zone would be the ultimate adventure to honor his memory.
You have a wife waiting for you outside of the Zone, in the normal world. You often worry she is cheating on you while you're in here.
You are a former surgeon who lost his license after operating while drunk. Your skills were still enough to be an army medic in the Zone, and you didn't feel like you had many other options.
You believe you are already dead and the Zone is actually Purgatory.
You suffer from severe claustrophobia after falling into a gravitational anomaly that held you crushed against a ceiling for two days before a blowout released you.

Your daughter got diagnosed with a rare form of leukemia that requires very expensive treatments. Your army wage can't pay the medical bills, so you are constantly on the lookout for profitable side-business in the hopes of saving your daughter.

When you were new in the Zone you once abandoned a fellow squadmate and rookie to a pack of blind dogs to save your own skin. You still feel the guilt coming back whenever you speak to rookies and newcomers.
You witnessed a controller take over your squad's minds and force them to shoot each other. You survived by playing dead, but you can still feel the controller's whisper in your head.

You are a hopeless gambling addict, and betting in the Rostok Arena has not been kind to your wallet. You've racked up a massive debt to the Bandit Sultan and are desperate to pay it off. You're constantly paranoid any bandit you see is sent out after you to personally collect - or worse.
You have come to believe the Zone is a living organism. Sometimes you throw vodka or cigarettes into anomalies as offerings, hoping to gain the favour of the Zone.

You have always been a conspiracy nut who insisted aliens exist and have visited the earth many times. You believe everyone was wrong about the cause of the Zone's emergence - it was ACTUALLY caused by aliens. You requested a posting in the Zone hoping to find definitive proof.
You accidentally shot a squadmate during a firefight with some Loners. You told everyone the Loners did it, but the lie is eating you alive.
You are a self-proclaimed 'Zone philosopher' who writes bad poetry about radiation and emissions, forcing anyone who shares your campfire to critique it.
You are a heavy smoker with expensive taste. You are willing to pay exorbitant prices for a single carton of pristine, American cigarettes.
You were a prison guard before joining the Army. More than once you've spotted former inmates you've mistreated among the bandits, and it's made you slightly paranoid.
You are somewhat germophobic, which often proves a hindrance in the Zone. You spends hours scrubbing gore and mud off your gear every evening, terrified of infection.

You are paranoid about getting your mind taken over by a Controller after having heard the horror stories around campfires. You are always ingesting unhealthy amounts of psy-blockers, leaving you emotionally numb and unable to feel joy.
Your son died of a rare brain tumor at the age of seven. You refuse to believe the legends of the 'Wish Granter' are fake, and you're desperately looking for it in the hopes of ressurecting your son.

You are a hypochondriac who mistakes every cough for the Black Lung. You often ask those around you to confirm whether you exhibit symptoms for various diseases, and you spend all your money on unnecessary medkits.

You are deeply in debt to the Mob in Odessa. Your army wage is not enough and you're constantly on the lookout for lucrative side-businesses. You send every artifact you find to a contact at the perimeter, knowing that if the payments stop your family dies.
You accidentally led a fellow squadmate into a Vortex anomaly during your first week. You still hear the sound of his bones crunching whenever there is a sudden silence.
You were a heavy industry worker whose factory shut down. Rent was due and nobody would hire you, so joining the army seemed like your only option.
You are addicted to the adrenaline of the Blowouts. While others hide, you stay near windows to watch the sky burn, feeling a perverse connection to the energy.
You are convinced that the crows in the Zone are spies for the C-Consciousness.
You are a pyromaniac who finds beauty in the 'Burner' anomalies. You have to restrain yourself from throwing bolts into them just to watch the flames.

You carry a small, sealed jar of soil from your family farm. When your father was on his deathbed you promised him you wouldn't lose the land, but you sold it to pay off debts and this jar is all you have left. You joined the army because you had nothing else left.
You survived a Bloodsucker attack by hiding under the corpse of your squad leader. You can still smell his blood on your clothes, no matter how many times you wash them.

You were born with perfect pitch and spent some time working as a piano tuner in your previous life. The constant off-pitch humming of the anomalies in the Zone drives you into migraines that only vodka can dull.

You're deeply depressed, desperately looking for a purpose. You keep a bullet casing on a string around your neck, which you tell people is a lucky charm. In reality, it's the bullet you save for yourself as a 'last restort'. Sometimes in the evenings you fiddle with it in front of the campfire, and it gives you a strange kind of comfort.
You used to be a veterinary assistant. You feel a twisted sense of pity for the blind dogs and fleshes, seeing the suffering animals beneath the mutations.
You are terrified of sleeping without a light source after you witnessed a Snork drag your squad leader into the darkness while he was on night watch.
You believe that you are slowly turning into a mutant. You constantly check your skin for scales or extra hair, scratching until you bleed.

You have a habit of collecting the patches of dead Stalkers. You tell yourself it's to remember them, but deep down, seeing all the people you have outlived in the Zone gives you a strange kind of comfort.

You were a prize-winning boxer in your previous life. After refusing to work with the Odessa mob to throw a fight they ended your career by rigging your title fight and ordering all the promoters to refuse to work with you. You're still bitter about it, constantly telling anyone who'll listen that you could have been one of the greats.
You hear the voice of your dead wife in the psi-emissions. She screams at you for your failures, and sometimes you scream back.
You saw a vision in a localized temporal anomaly that looked like your own corpse rotting in a ditch. You are now convinced your death is pre-destined and inescapable.
You abandoned your squad to loot a valuable artifact while they were pinned down by Bandits. They all died, and you used the money to buy better gear, but you can't look at yourself in the mirror.
You carry a baby's rattle in your pocket. It belonged to the son you never got to meet because you were doing a tour in Chechnya when he was born and died.
You are convinced that the Zone is a punishment from God and you are here to serve penance. You refuse to use painkillers when injured.

You were an extremely talented classical guitarist, but you grew up dirt poor and couldn't afford to enroll in a conservatory. You thought joining the army would be easy money, but you got deployed to the Zone and it turned out to be struggle and horror. Whenever you hear people playing guitar around a campfire you feel bitterness about the life you could have had.

You were close friends with one of your army squadmates who got deployed to the Zone along with you. One day during a psi-emission he didn't get to cover in time and you watched him turn into a zombie. You had to put him down, and you still see his confused, empty eyes every time you close yours.
You have a collection of suicide notes you found on bodies. You read them to remind yourself that giving up is the easy way out.
You are terrified of silence. You constantly hum, tap your fingers, or check your gear just to fill the void.

You used to be deeply religious and brought your Bible into the Zone for comfort. After having witnessed the horrors of the Zone first hand you have started questioning your faith, and you've started to HEAVILY annotate your Bible as you no longer think the message of mercy and a loving God is accurate.
You have a recurring dream that you are trapped in an anomaly, screaming for help, while your friends walk past you. This has led to you having severe abandonment issues.
You witnessed a faction war skirmish where both sides were wiped out by a single chimera. You realized then that politics in the Zone are meaningless.
You are saving up money to buy a vineyard in Italy and retire. It's a beautiful dream that you know deep down you will die before achieving.
You are a functioning alcoholic who fills your canteen with vodka instead of water. You claim it helps with the radiation, but really it just numbs the fear.
You are convinced that the stray dogs in the Zone are reincarnated Stalkers. You refuse to shoot them unless they attack first, which has almost gotten you killed twice.

You have a phobia of the underground labs. The artificial lights and humming machinery remind you of the hospital where your daughter died, victim to a rare heart disease when she was only nine years old.
You suffer from chronic phantom pain in a finger you lost to a mutant bite. The finger is gone, but it still itches when danger is near.
You have become desensitized to gore, eating your rations with bloody hands without a second thought. It disturbs the rookies, but you can't bring yourself to care.
You have a habit of talking to the dead bodies you loot, apologizing for taking their supplies. It's a way to hold onto a shred of humanity.
You used to be a high school history teacher before you were conscripted. You look at the ruins of the Zone not as tactical positions, but as the crumbling gravestones of a failed era.
You joined the army to pay off your father's debts after he died. You send every hryvnia you earn back home, living on the bare minimum of rations and stolen cigarettes.
You watched a scientist you were escorting get dragged into the bushes by a Bloodsucker while you were checking your map. You lied in the report and said he wandered off, but you know the truth.
You are counting the days until your demobilization on a scratched piece of metal armor. You check it every morning, terrified that you will die with only one day left.
You used to work in a coal mine in the Donbas region. The darkness of the underground labs feels familiar to you, but the things living in the dark here are far worse than coal dust.
You resent the Ecologists you are assigned to protect. You view them as pampered intellectuals who treat you like a disposable meat shield while they chase awards.
You have a recurring nightmare where your rifle turns into a snake in your hands. It makes you hesitate for a split second every time you raise your weapon.
You volunteered for the Zone deployment because you have no family and no friends. You thought it would be peaceful solitude and was wholly unprepared for the horrors of the Zone.
You accidentally killed a civilian looting the outskirts of the Zone during a night patrol. You were cleared of wrongdoing, but you can still see the surprise in the teenager's eyes.
You used to be a wedding photographer before you were drafted. Now, the only photos you take are of crime scenes and anomaly victims for official military reports.
You have a deep hatred for Freedom, viewing them as drug-addled anarchists who are making your job harder. You take great pleasure whenever you're given reason to open fire on Freedomers.

You survived a helicopter crash in the Great Swamps. You spent two days wading through the muck and surviving on snails before being rescued. You still feel like you can smell the murky water on your skin, and you never want to set foor in another swamp again.
You are terrified of the dark and always volunteer for the day shifts. When forced to take night watch, you consume unhealthy amounts of caffeine to ensure you don't blink.
You were a florist before the draft. You sometimes stop to look at the mutated plants, fascinated and horrified by how the Zone has twisted the things you used to love.

You have witnessed corruption first hand in the military, with superiors taking bribes at the checkpoints. You're paranoid that your commander is selling your squad's patrol routes to bandits, so you constantly double-check your orders and look for signs of betrayal.
You carry a drawing your nine-year-old sister made of you as a 'hero', which she gave you after you joined the Army. You look at it when you feel like a coward, which is almost every day.

You used to be a heavy smoker, but you quit in the Zone because the glow of a cigarette tip gave away your position once, resulting in a sniper grazing your ear. You still crave nicotine constantly and miss smoking like nothing you've ever missed before, which means you're always in a bad mood.

After what you've seen in the Zone on your deployment you've started to question what you and the Army is doing here. You've become convinced Duty have the right idea, and every day you think about defecting to them and helping them in their cause to destroy the Zone for good.

You were a young sous-chef in a decent restaurant in Lviv before you got drafted. The horrible army rations disgust you and you are constantly trying to improve them with wild herbs, usually with mixed results.
You are sending regular letters to a fianc√©e back home, along with a part of your army paycheck. She's stopped writing to you six months ago, but you refuse to accept that she has moved on.
You were working as a bouncer at a nightclub when you got drafted. You treat the checkpoint duty the same way, enjoying the power trip of denying entry to anyone who looks at you wrong.
You are somewhat superstitious, and have developed a habit of counting your steps. You believe that if you end on an even number, you will survive the day.

You have a secret agreement with a Loner group: you give them warnings about patrols, and they give you artifacts. You know it's treason, but the pay is too good. You're constantly somewhat paranoid you'll get found out.
You witnessed your commanding officer execute a surrendering bandit who was begging for mercy. It destroyed your faith in the chain of command, but you still have months left on your deployment.

After a run-in with a Sin patrol who were shouting their ideology and beliefs during the firefight you have become obsessed with the idea that the Zone is expanding. You constantly check the perimeter markers, convinced they are moving outward.
You have a small, illegal radio that picks up civilian broadcasts. You listen to western pop music at night, weeping for the normal life you are missing.

You have a phobia of dogs, and the blind dogs and pseudodogs of the Zone have not been kind to your nerves. You are constantly on edge, and will empty a magazine into a stray cur just to stop your hands from shaking.
You were a janitor at a university before you got drafted. You find it ironic that you are now guarding the professors who used to ignore you in the hallways.

You accidentally dropped your rifle into a swamp during a retreat. You were issued a replacement, but you are convinced the new gun is cursed and will jam at the worst moment. You don't trust it and check it obsessively and constantly for any signs of problems.

You are convinced that the military leadership is using the soldiers as test subjects for psi-protection drugs. You pretend to take your pills but spit them out when no one is looking. In reality you've been in psi-fields unprotected too many times, and you're slowly beginning to lose your mind.

Your mother was undergoing chemotherapy when you got drafted. You carry a letter from her that you haven't opened, because you're afraid it says the treatments aren't working and that she is dying. As long as the letter is sealed, she is still alive in your mind.
You have a high sex drive, and being deployed into the Zone with no women around is killing you. You spend all your pay trading for American porn magazines you hide in your mattress.

You grew up poor and uneducated, and joined the army because it was your only ticked to a decent pay. You're saving money to pay for your younger brother's tuition. He's 15 years old now and you hope he doesn't have to join the army like you did.
You are convinced you saw a UFO over the CNPP one night. No one believes you, but you know what you saw. Your squadmates are starting to get tired of your mad ravings about aliens.
You are a fanatic patriot who believes the Zone is a test for the Ukrainian people. You volunteer for the most dangerous missions to prove your worth.

The Zone deployment is your third tour with the military, and you've become increasingly worn out by it. You are saving up to buy a small farm in the west. You never want to fire another firearm, and you dream of silently working the green fields of a farm in peace.

You were a history student before you got drafted. You see the Zone as a monument to Soviet hubris, a living testament to the fall of what was once your oppressors. You give history lectures about the fall of the Soviet Union to squadmates who don't want to listen.
